Subject: Sensitive Data False Positives    [ ref:!00D70091pB.!500Qk0NrOBr:ref ]

TextBody:
Hi John,

My internal testing indicates that wildcards should work as you have indicated.  With the current configuration, you need to set the false positive (Settings > Sensitive Data > False Positives) prior to running the full FileSystem collection and collecting them.


Thank you,
Mike Candon
Senior Technical Support Engineer
__________________ _________
Powerful Data Security Made Easy
6160 Warren Parkway, Suite 100, Frisco, TX 75034
www.netwrix.com

TextBody:
Hi John,
I am glad that we were able to get your issue resolved.
The following is a summary of the ticket for your records.

Following this email, you will receive an automated confirmation that the case is closed, along with the ability to re-open the case if any related errors return. In addition, you will also receive a separate email with a survey where you can let us know how we did. Feel free to leave any feedback via the survey link!
+++++
Adding False Positive Exclusion Filters
https://helpcenter.netwrix.com/bundle/EnterpriseAuditor_11.6/page/Content/EnterpriseAuditor/Admin/Settings/SensitiveData/Exclusions/Add.htm

+++++
NEA v11.6 - False Positives Tab
https://helpcenter.netwrix.com/bundle/EnterpriseAuditor_11.6/page/Content/EnterpriseAuditor/Admin/Settings/SensitiveData/Exclusions/Overview.htm

+++++
My internal testing indicates that wildcards should work as you have indicated.  With the current configuration, you need to set the false positive (Settings > Sensitive Data > False Positives) prior to running the full FileSystem collection and collecting them.

Can you use wildcards for the Sensitive Data False Positives? 
For example UNC:
\pcnamefolder1*.txt or \pcnamefolder1data*.txt?

Thank you,
Mike Candon
Senior Technical Support Engineer
__________________ _________

6160 Warren Parkway, Suite 100, Frisco, TX 75034
www.netwrix.com
